prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal: AFGL2591 HCN 4-3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
AFGL 2591 is a testbed of high-mass star formation that has unusually high HCN abundance (Boonman et al. (2001)). According to Benz et al. (2007) and references therein, it can be also be classified as a high mass protostellar object (HMPO) or early “Hot Core.” HMPOs are distinctive stages of star formation in which the sources are bright in the mid-infrared (10-12μm) and show a central density concentration. In this phase, the protostellar object is still deeply embedded in a collapsing dusty envelope. These high-mass objects can effectively heat their envelope by FUV radiation.
Vibrationally excited HCN is particularly powerful because it enables disk structure to be probed without spatially resolving that structure. Success of our observations does not require that we resolve the source of vibrationally excited HCN emission (although such an occurrence would be welcome). The ALMA compact configuration results in a relatively large beam size of 1.4” (1200 AU for IRAS 16293), decreasing the likelihood that vibrational emission will be resolved.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
All of the relevant spectral lines (HCN v=0, v=11c, v=11d, v=20, v=22c and v=22d), can be observed in a single pointing using two 1875 MHz spectral windows. The corresponding spectral resolution of ~0.8 km/s is similar to the SMA resolution (0.8 km/s) and sufficient to resolve the narrowest lines seen in the SMA pilot observations (2-3 km/s). We will also extract continuum data from these observations to determine any spatial offsets between dust continuum and line emission.
For each of the 4 sources, one pointing of ALMA is requested. We have proposed for integration times that are likely to result in the detection of HCN(4-3) v=2 lines of at least S/N~10. See table 1 for associated sensitivities requested. We have used the SMA observations of AFGL2591 and HHT observations of IRAS16293-2522 to determine these sensitivity levels. Using the observed HCN(4-3) v=2 line intensity (the weakest line detected) from our SMA observations of AFGL2591, we have determined the observing time necessary to detect those lines in our proposed high mass source. We scale the required line sensitivity derived from AFGL2591 by the 100 μm flux ratio of the proposed sources normalized to AFGL2591. We do a similar calculation for the low mass sources using the marginal HCN(4-3) v=2 detections in IRAS16293-2522, again scaling by 100 μm flux ratio after taking into account the 120x reduction in beam dilution with ALMA. We take 50 mJy as a minimum sensitivity since time on source for this sensitivity level is very short (less than 5 minutes), and we have not considered variation in HCN abundance in our sample which could effect these time estimates by a factor of several.
Since the goal of the observations is entirely spectral in nature with emission regions that are likely to be unresolved, UV plane coverage issues from the short integration times are not relevant. There is no need to segment integration time on the proposed sources to improve UV plane coverage.
The technical implementation of this project is straightforward, with only a few pointings of short duration using a simple instrument configuration. The two hours requested in this proposal is likely to immediately produce conclusive results. Reduction and analysis of the data are straightforward, and should quickly demonstrate the efficacy of vibrationally excited HCN(4-3) in tracing structure around high and low mass protostellar sources.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Vibrationally excited molecules with submm rotational transitions are excellent probes of physical conditions in compact regions very near protostars. The proposed ALMA study uses a novel technique to study this environment with observations of the v=1 and v=2 vibrational modes of HCN(4-3). The presence/absence and relative strengths of these vibrational lines probe the gas excitation mechanism and physical conditions in hot, dense material associated with protostellar disks and/or that may be penetrated by infrared radiation. The entire suite of vibrationally excited lines (HCN(4-3) v=0, v=1, and v=2 lines) can be observed in one tuning of the ALMA 345 GHz receivers. Results from a study using this technique with SMA yield several potential sources for further study using the ALMA, including AFGL 2591 (a source with unusually high HCN abundance). High angular resolution and improved sensitivity observations achievable in one track per source with the ALMA in the compact configuration will elucidate the gas excitation mechanism, helping pinpoint the origin of the vibrationally excited emission, and revealing physical characteristics of collisionally excited emitting material.
